What is the role of such watchers? To react to what already has a "context", so it has meaning & significance? One would have thought the opposite: They are there to detect facts, context or no, and report them up.
At Pearl Harbor the operator apparently used a context (returning American planes) he invented; and which actually shows him to be useless for any purpose.
OC the report level does not like being needlessly disturbed, thus the "trivial bureaucratic concerns".
How many dozens or hundreds of useless screen watchers are "working" right now?

Radishes -- There are no "facts" without contexts.  Roberta Wohlstetter in her book stated, if she didn't first articulate, the problem of the signal to noise ratio:  how does a watcher of incoming data decide what's interesting data and what is just irrelevant system noise?  It's sorted differently than in 1941 but the problem remains.  It is actaully not possible to "report facts, context or no"  -- the system would be overwhelmed.  What are needed are more expert contextualizers at lower levels.

The recent incident of an American officer and two enlisted men failing to track Malaysian Flight 370 after it was detected at their installation illustrates Shelling's argument nicely.  Why did they choose to ignore the event?  The fact that they had no idea of its context or significance allowed what we might now see as trivial bureaucratic or personal concerns to cloud their judgement.

Come a Republican victory in the Senate and or White House and we can count on slipping back to pre-Great Depression era policy.
.

Donations of food, money, supplies and support have poured into Oso, Washington, since the first moment of the March 22 landslide. Neighbors risked their lives in the early moments to attempt rescues.

When the Great Alaska Earthquake struck on March 27, 1964 Federal emergency and civilian aid poured in to aid the victims.

After the attack on Pearl Harbor Dec 7 1941 the nation threw itself into war against Japan, and within days against Germany. Hundreds of thousands of Americans died for their nation.

During The Great Depression charity sprang up nationwide to aid the destitute; the Roosevelt administration threw itself into reversing an economy that favored the wealthy. Marginal tax rates rose to heights that stayed with the nation from then until the Kennedy administration.

The nation prospered.

Every national mobilization to help has succeeded.

And since 2008 Conservative policy has stonewalled every effort to help Americans unemployed, foreclosed out of their homes, without health insurance, without education, without futures.

Yet name one, single, well reasoned broadly supported and endorsed proposal by Republicans to reverse the trend.

Instead they propose further tax cuts, cuts to food stamps, reversing Affordable Care, and onerous austerity measures at precisely a time that economic history shows we should be doing the direct opposite.

Want to see a Republican future? Look at Europe.

Robust American economic growth has typically been the product of strong consumer purchasing. The erosion of mass market growth due to the concentration of income in fewer hands weakens the foundation on which our economy stands.

You have suggested that the positive feedbacks which were part of the thesis are real, and if so should be operative, this is what Hansen predicted and was part of the 'simple settled physics'. If they arrive at some future date unspecified and unknown, then we really do not have even a basic understanding about climate at this stage.

An open-ended thesis isn't science, it's astrology of sorts. It fails every real test for validity and certainly cannot be the basis for radical action.

Climate has changed rapidly in the past, both directions, there is no indication any of these were driven primarily by carbon, or even materially by carbon. Even the most remarkable of these, the PETM, was preceded by an extremely warm period and trend of thousands of years, BEFORE the carbon bloom, and even then, said carbon can account for just half (-) of the warming, leaving the rest to speculation.

Indian democracy is based on group rights, rural vs urban, yes caste, rich vs poor,business interests, minority rights. This deliberate misreading of Indian politics as dominated by upper castes, is flawed. The past 30 years have seen a huge churn and many smaller groups have become assertive. In Andhra , Telanagana movement has challenged the hegemony of the kappas and Reddys. Its all about representation and the fight for that. More political change has taken place in India, than in the UK where a few public schools still rule the roost. The CM of India's largest Northern state was a  woman dalit . Brahmins have not been in power for decades. The Congress has had a residual national hold and branding, and money to play the game. The new challenger Modi, darling of the middle class is a low caste chaiwallh. Do your research. Politics is local and fragmented.

It's not only the bankers who've been making out like bandits.  The CEOs (aka the "job creators") have been swimming in profits during the Obama administration but where are the jobs?  The favorable tax laws that they more or less wrote themselves have allowed them to benefit from subsidies that aren't available to the rest of us.  And yet employment is down, salaries are down and benefits are down.  When jobs are created they're almost invariably filled by more sophisticated computers or by low-wage employees overseas.  It's high time that corporate taxes were tied inextricably to employment: i.e., create some jobs (here in the U.S.) and THEN we'll talk about lowering your taxes. Or, anyway, not raising them...

Forget about fairness or morality. Let's just look at economics to see why inequality is bad.

Experiments are hard to come by in economics, but we have a couple in the US to look at since WWI. There have been two medium long periods of very high inequality (Gini about 0.5), the 1920's and the 2000's. Both led to periods of disastrous economics, On the other hand, there was the long period of 1946 - 1973 (Gini about 0.25) which was a period of great prosperity. Since I do not place much faith in any economic theory, this evidence makes me believe that high inequality is very bad for the country.

But I know people like explanations. The want to know why. So I'll give it a shot.

1. Inequality depresses demand. A non-rich person must spend a greater percentage of his income to live than a Rich one. When many people are out of work, or are underpaid, when inequality is high, the non-rich do not have enough money to buy the stuff they need or want. They may want a new car, but they cannot afford it. This means businesses are not expanding because they do not have enough customers. You cannot create demand out of thin air. It requires getting money to people to spend it.

2. Inequality encourages financial speculation. What do the Rich do when they have so much money they cannot remember how many houses they own? They speculate with it. There is a definite correlation.. http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1661746

What does wild speculation do? See 1929 & 2008

Len:

Your habitual carping about speculation by the rich merely demonstrates the premise on which your distaste is built: that all production is a collective asset; so, any idle speculation merely robs the collective of resources that properly belong to it but are squandered by those who merely produce those resources.

Your premise is invalid, so try to get over your distaste: what people produce largely is theirs to do with as they please. It's not society's business to be spanking them for what some believe are bad choices. It's not your money.

Richard, don't put words in my mouth. I never said anything like " all production is a collective asset."

My point is simply that inequality produces wild speculation which is bad for the economy. Th two ideas are not related in any way.

The views got pushed out of the mainstream when levels of taxation in real terms started to get absurd.

Teddy Roosevelt was talking about an inheritance tax, not outrageously high taxes on earnings that would have seriously constraining effects on the right to keep money people made themselves. Some wax outraged that marginal federal income tax rates of 80% or more were imposed on high incomes, but they conveniently forget to admit that this was when states did not tax income as well, or when such taxes were insignificant. Equally convenient a lapse is not mentioning that deductions that shielded much of that income were numerous in the past and have today become almost non-existent through the Alternative Minimum Tax.

The Professor conflates taxes on accumulated wealth at death with taxes on incomes earned during life, and seeks to co-opt the iconic stature of Teddy Roosevelt as if 100 years ago he was defending a grasping government looking to milk every dime from anyone who can pay. TR certainly wasn't doing that -- that's a feature of today's Democratic Party, and clearly one The Professor wishes to evangelize.

What's more, the notion that Jefferson's generation had a general problem with inherited wealth is just as absurd. Without such wealth, Jefferson and others would not have had the leisure to draft a Declaration of Independence, two constitutions, or serve in innumerable state and federal offices. The same certainly could be said of BOTH Roosevelts.
Hopefully it ends up looking like any number of countries whose average citizen already gets better medical care for less cost than the citizens of the US. Wouldn't that be strange?

The ACA is absolutely necessary, the US is spending way too much on healthcare. Now physicians are rewarded when they order more tests and procedures some of which are dangerous and deadly offering no benefits.

The CEO of Mayo Clinic said they were planning on a 10 to 20% reduction in income and a huge increase in the number of patients they have to see.

When the quality of care requirements are installed which maybe a long time due to the botched ACA rollout - then the healthcare industry will really go though some drastic changes. It is fair to assume we will see a reduction in the numbers of physicians and an increased use of RN's.

Nobody knows where this will end up.

But the ruling doesn't apply to non-scholarship athletes. Why would the ruling prompt colleges to drop football?

Let's say a college currently pays 20 of the players on its team with scholarships valued at $5m per year. Those athletes unionize and bargain for better health insurance, a longer time to graduate (so they can take real classes after their playing eligibility runs out), and pay at market rates in American dollars instead of at an artificially-low rate in nontransferrable tuition discounts. These costs add up to $10m per year. Would the college cut the whole football program (out of spite? why?), or would it bring its costs back into line by simply reducing the number of athlete-employees from 20 to 10?

Collegiate football programs pay for all other sports on campuses,
except for basketball which is self-sustaining. But if a college can
save 55 scholarships plus the cost of coaching and administrative
expenses, it will have enough funding to carry the other sports
without football.

The NLRB decision provides colleges with a fig-leaf to drop football;
something they are inclined towards anyway. Using professors to
teach students who have no academic credentials is an insult
to educators. If these athletes can be replaced with academically
endowed students, the professors will be happier and the rankings of
colleges without football teams will rise significantly.

I am personally familiar with the football team at Wake Forest College, which
has an undergraduate enrollment of 4,000, 55 football scholarships, and is the doormat of the ACC. Replacing 55 semi-literate athletes with places for 55 academically superior students will enhance the value of its degree for present and future students. This is a more salutary goal that moving pigskin across white lines.

Rey Olsen
President
World Sports Group

Businesses can have all the tax breaks in the world but if they have no one to sell goods and services to, they won't invest or hire.
So let's transfer as much wealth to the poor and what's left of the middle class. They are the real job creators and a more equitable distribution of wealth and income will make everyone richer, including the 1%ers,

When the second Vice President under Lincoln was from Tennessee it is obvious that some of the South could not except the idea of destroying the Union. Also western North Carolina, Northern Alabama, and Eastern Tennessee along with the Free State of Jones in Mississippi and Sam Houston's opposition to secession are indicative of the less than monolithic views of the South. I would think that today's Republican party, with a faction insisting on ideological  purity over reason, resembled what went on inside the Civil War South. Looks like reason doesn't always prevail.

@ Dennis G

Yes, there were slaveholders fighting on the Union side. The most notable example was U.S. Grant whose wife owned slaves.

Of course, many will claim *he* was not a slaveholder because it was only his wife who owned them Such people will say in the same breath that General Robert E. Lee was a slaveholder and the fact that his family's slaves were owned by his wife is a mere technicality.

@SimpleBSimpson

Grant and Lee are not at all comparable in this regard. The former fought (among other things) to preserve the Federal government's ability to *limit* the institution of slavery, and ordered that his troops were not to return escaped slaves to their former masters. The latter fought to *preserve* the institution of slavery, and when his troops captured people who they assumed were escaped slaves they either returned them to their former masters or sold them to new ones!

It is true that Grant's wife owned slaves, but there is no record that he ever personally approved of the institution. It is quite plausible that he simply forbore to speak out about it so as not to offend the woman he loved. Such situations happen to many men. Since he grew up in the free state of Ohio and went from there into the military, he was certainly used to living on his own without depending upon the labor of others.

Lee, on the other hand, had grown up in a slave-owning household. As a grown man he was certainly the master of his plantation and personally commanded his family's slaves no matter who was technically the "owner".

Your statement is ridiculous.

The political in-fighting in the Confederate government has never gotten the amount of attention, as that in the Federal government. Much has been written, or portrayed on film, of the Lincoln Administration's opposition from both Radical Republicans and Copperheads, and of various degrees in between. Conversely, less well-known are the oppositional elements to the Davis Administration, or the political factions within the CSA. Stephens is one face of this opposition, as were Louis T. Wigfall, and Joseph Brown, among others.

As this article points out, Confederate politics were hardly monolithic or harmonious. That may well discomfort both Lost Cause revisionists, and rabid South-bashers, who frequently comment in these spaces. Both seem loth to admit there were shades of gray among the shades of gray.

" .. Nonprofitable sports programs, now subsidized by basketball and football in some cases, might shrink .."

"Might?" That's like calling an H-bomb a "small firecracker." Football pays for 90-plus percent of women's sports. Weaken football -- weaken women's sports.

As to "fair treatment" -- those involved eliminated five other students for their scholarships. Was that "fair" to them?

Of course not. As JFK noted: "life isn't fair."

E.T.-Colleges do NOT need to be organized sports meccas. They need to EDUCATE. So what? If all other athletic departments are eliminated? The only responsibility colleges have to their students is to provide education and a means for healthy support. Intramural activity is enough to satisfy this.

Let ALL students be required to take 1 physical education class each semester to maintain their healthy well-being and be required to pass a swimming test and first aid with CPR before graduation.

College athletes in high profile sports certainly are "employees" who happen to be paid via a barter system. Often their pay is paltry compared with the value of their performance and the real health risks (short and long term) that they are exposed to. When this occurs they are entitled to compensation and protection. Universities should be ashamed that athletes need to unionize in order to be treated fairly.

"As inequality has become an increasingly prominent issue in American discourse..."

No, it hasn't. Income inequality is an increasingly prominent issue in Democratic Party discourse and in liberal editorial page discourse but it most certainly isn't in American discourse. Quite simply, the American people see talk about income equality for what it really is; an attempt by Democrats to change the narrative from the failures of the Obama administration's economic policies, not to mention Obamacare.

http://thehill.com/blogs/on-the-money/economy/201752-obamas-populist-pit...

Minimum wage hikes, Koch bashing and income inequality are all attempts to rile the Democratic base in an attempt to avert an electoral disaster in November. These 'issues' may play well to the Democratic focus groups but they don't resonate with a public focused on jobs and health care.

In all likelihood, The ACA is not going to change "responsiveness"-- medical conditions being diagnosed and treated.  It will enable more people to benefit from that "responsiveness."  People do not say our doctors are poor.  Basically, it is about the excessive cost of using a middleman; ie insurance company that adds to the cost drastically.  So, in one sense we have not fixed that with continuing the same system.  However, if more people can be insured at a reasonable price and get the medical treatment they need, then it is a step in the right direction.

And he sure did try!! The frustration in 2009-2010 was palpable.  And Republicans sure did not start out with any intentions of aiding in the process.  Only when they could jump in and criticize did they participate with enthusiasm.  By the way, none of it should have been about making a deal.  It should be about working cooperatively so that the greatest number of people should be well-served.  Now THAT attitude would create less divisiveness for sure.
There will be no such count. Most who "lost" their insurance had it replaced with another policy at the same company and they had no need to use the federal site to buy new insurance.

On the contrary - most of those benefiting from Obamacare are taxpaying, hardworking people who simply can't afford high-priced insurance under the old system - or who couldn't get insurance due to "previous conditions."

The "middle class" includes independent professionals and freelancers; most of academia now is staffed by adjuncts who work without a steady paycheck or employer insurance. Most low-wage jobs now are less than full-time, so employers can avoid paying any benefits - so low-wage workers often work 2-3 jobs to make ends meet - & still pay taxes.

Nearly all adults pay taxes - if they're too poor to pay Federal income taxes, they still pay local taxes, fees, tolls, sales taxes, surcharges, etc.

Like so many millions of your fellow Americans, I've worked hard all my life as a middle class professional - & still do - but now struggle financially. I'm grateful to have good health insurance under Obamacare - for which btw, I pay full price, as thankfully, my income isn't low enough to qualify for subsidies.

I'm so tired of people calling the poor "freeloaders" as if living in poverty is a life of fun & leisure. If you really believe that, give away all your money & possessions - & see how much fun it is.

And don't forget - all it takes is one crisis, one streak of bad luck - & all too quickly, you, too can know the "joys" of poverty.

Media coverage of the ACA, continually focusing on its supposed faults and problems, while essentially ignoring the fact that millions of Americans are now able to obtain affordable health insurance for the first time, has been atrocious. It's time the media woke up and stopped being puppets for Republican spin. By any reasonable measure, the ACA has been a great success already and its beneficial effects will only grow with time. When will the media start the cover the real story?

The Right will never be able to take away the major benefits that people are now getting, such as not becoming uninsurable once you become sick. This imperfect plan will improve, and Republicans will have to try to find something else to moan about. May their millions spent on trashing the ACA be wasted.
